key_points: Two days after the Taliban took over Kabul, Washington Post staff were offered a chance to escape on a chartered plane to Qatar.
Security around Kabul's airport was deteriorating, making the journey to the airport the most challenging part.
The group faced dangerous conditions and Taliban checkpoints en route to the airport.
Washington Post reporter Aziz Tassal and his daughter were previously beaten by Taliban fighters while trying to flee.
The Biden administration was escalating evacuation plans, but could not ensure safe passage to the airport.
British troops assisted the group in bypassing a Taliban checkpoint to reach the airport.
The group used rented armored cars for safety and encountered desperate families and damaged vehicles along the way.
Upon reaching the military base, there were initial fears that no charter planes would land that day.
An American military officer arranged for the group to leave on a U.S. military flight to Qatar.
The flight was packed with mostly Afghans, with seats removed to accommodate more people.
